text.p: Chrysler Corp said it is consolidating the internal operations of its Chrysler/Plymouth and Jeep/Eagle divisions as part of a long-term streamlining plan.
The automaker said Dodge division General Manager Martin Levine was named general manager of the combined Chrysler/Plymouth and Jeep/Eagle unit.

Ray Fisher, formerly Chrysler/Plymouth general manager, will now head the Dodge car and truck operations. Edwin Brust, formerly Jeep/Eagle general manager, will be appointed to a new position that will be announced separately.

Chrysler spokeswoman Terri Houtman said any reduction in the company's marketing staffs due to the consolidation will be handled through a previously announced early retirement incentive offer to 1,200 U.S. and Canadian salaried employees during the third quarter.
The automaker plans to take a $50 million to $100 million pre-tax charge against third quarter earnings to cover costs of the early retirements.
"It's a complete, top-to-bottom reorganization" that also includes the automaker's Dodge division, Houtman said.

The changes in part are aimed at improving the focus of the automaker's four major brands -- Chrysler, Plymouth, Jeep and Eagle -- and are compatible with the automaker's dealership consolidation effort, she said.

In 1991, Chrysler began to combine its Chrysler/Plymouth and Jeep/Eagle dealerships under a plan called Project 2000. Currently, about half of the dealers selling those brands offer them under a single roof.
